titleStmt.title: Minutes of Historical Advisory Committee Meeting, May 1994
HAC Meeting Minutes, 1994

div.head: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HISTORICAL DIPLOMATIC DOCUMENTATION May 5 and 6, 1994

list.item: Kenneth Rossman, Chief, Records Management IS/OIS/RA/RD
George C. Chalou, Archivist, Records Appraisal Division
David A. Langbart, Archivist, Records Appraisal and Disposition Division
Jerome Nashorn, Chief, Military Appraisal Branch
Marvin Russell, Chief, General Archives Review Branch
Page Putnam Miller, Director, National Coordinating Committee for Promotion of History
Karen Gatz, Department of Justice, Office of Special Investigations

div.p: The Advisory Committee convened at 9:12 a.m.
Kimball asked the Committee members if anyone had any objections to the agenda. No one objected. He asked the Committee members for written comments for the Annual Report.

Bennett Freeman entered at 9:18 a.m. He said he had spoken to all but one of the Committee members prior to today’s meeting, and that he had shared the Department’s response regarding PRD-29 with all the members by mail. He said that he was satisfied that members of the Department who wrote the Department’s response to PRD-29 had fully heard the Committee’s views. He acknowledged that a 25 year declassification line was desirable but not attainable; because of a lack of resources, only a 30 year line was feasible. He added that the Advisory Committee oversight mechanism should value its role and the future role of the academic community. The Bureau of Public Affairs (PA) is satisfied that the Committee’s views were heard and aired fully in the Department. He said the Department’s response and the Interagency response were sent to the National Security Council (NSC). He said that the Committee could discuss PRD-29 but that the Department could not make any further response. Finally, he said the drafters of the Department’s response had heard the Advisory Committee’s views though they had not adopted them completely.
Herring asked, when will the process end?
Freeman said the NSC’s redraft is underway taking into account the Interagency response, but he himself did not know when the final PRD-29 draft would be ready.
Kimball asked whether the Department’s response would include the roles of the academic and scholarly communities.
Freeman said, yes, and he was willing to send a letter to the NSC to seek clarification on this point.
Freeman was thanked for coming to the meeting and sharing his views on how the Committee’s views on PRD-29 were being handled. He exited at 9:28 a.m.
Kimball asked if the revised agenda was adopted. The committee members assented.

The report on the status of the Foreign Relations of the United States series was given by William Z. Slany, the Historian. Slany said the series was proceeding approximately on schedule. He said the 1980’s volumes being published now do not reflect changes in the standards of publication brought on by the FRUS legislation. Slany said there was one retirement (Charles Sampson), and he introduced two new historians, Dr. Karen Gatz and Mr. Daniel Lawler. He added that it was difficult to hire new employees because of complicated personnel rules.
Kimball asked if there was a funding problem?

Slany replied that he was concerned with government downsizing, but that the Historical Office (HO) is authorized to recruit and maintain staff at the level of a few years ago. He went on to say that HO is unable to continue the Current Documents series; 75 percent of the information in Current Documents is already printed in Dispatch and that the remaining 25 percent would be added to a CD-ROM. He said the CD-ROM will have more information than the Current Documents series.
Kimball asked if the CD-ROM would be distributed automatically to all government depository libraries.
Slany said yes.
Kimball asked whether letters were sent to Journals to inform the public about these changes.
Slany said he wanted to discuss this first with the Committee and that McCurry was concerned.
Rosenberg asked if there would be a timelag caused by the discontinuation of the Current Documents series as it exists now and the proposed transference of it onto CD-ROM.
Slany said no.
Picker asked if Dispatch was on CD-ROM.
Slany said yes, and that there is search software.
Kimball asked if the Committee was satisfied? No one objected so Kimball said the Committee concurred with this change.

Slany then discussed the Committee’s Charter (TAB C [package distributed to the Committee members prior to the meeting]). He said that the Federal Advisory Committee Act requires charter renewal every two years; and that the only change in the Charter is an increase in the amount of money needed to sustain the Committee. He then discussed the question of dissemination of Advisory Committee documents. He asked if the charter was adequate to deal with the dissemination of information that HAC receives.

Kimball said that the Advisory Committee is responsible to the public through the organizations it represents. He said that the Committee has access to privileged information of ongoing discussions within the Department which State does not want released to the public. He said the amount of information the Committee receives would be affected by whether it accepts restrictions on release of privileged information. He said the Committee needs full access to advise the Secretary of State and that by reason of law it cannot be excluded. He asked how to deal with privileged information and how to deal with “outside” information.
Nelson said the Department decides and the Committee abides by the decision. She said it was up to the Department to decide what is privileged information.
Glad asked how is privileged information handled now?

Machak said that the majority of officials don’t mark privileged information, and that it is dealt with on a case by case basis. He said there is a chilling effect when comments of officials get into the hands of an audience outside the decision making body when there is considerable disagreement among officials about the Executive Order.
Picker added that she thought it was the Department’s responsibility to define what is privileged information.

Machak said that the principle of “need to know” is applied by senior officials in regard to dissemination of information. He said that they have the prerogative to decide when to bring in other people into the decision making process.

Kimball said the Committee has outside responsibilities. He wanted to assure the Department that they are not nine loose canons, but at the same time they cannot stop discussing not-yet-decided issues with their constituents. He said that there were rumblings that the Committee had revealed privileged information on PRD-29 discussions in the state Department.
Slany said nothing given to the Committee is withheld except classified documents. He said all the rest of the information is open.

Kimball said there is no Committee statement or rule to solve this problem but that the Committee will handle privileged information in a responsible way. At the same time, he said that there will be times when the Committee “will do “otherwise.” But in such cases, he said, the Committee will discuss it with the Department.
Machak said he was unaware of any criticism of the Committee but that there was uncertainty within the building about when to ask the Committee for advice.
Kimball said that if the Advisory Committee is not engaged until late in the process, then it cannot be effective. He went on to ask when the Department’s fiscal year ends.
Slany said it ends on September 30.
Kimball said the Committee turns over on August 31, one month short of the fiscal year but that this would not affect the Committee’s access to the Secretary.
Glad asked what happens to the Committee’s papers?
Langbart said the Committee’s records are retired to the Archives after two years.

Herschler delivered his report (Tab E). He said that delays by the CIA in declassifying FRUS manuscripts have resulted in a backlog of 15 volumes, a 1-1/2 year delay. However, under a crash program 12 volumes were cleared for the NSC, but only 2 volumes have been cleared for typesetting. The remaining volume is at the CIA. He also said the NSC is on schedule with the declassification deadline.

Kimball said that he had spoken to John Pereira and that he was aware of the problem and that Pereira would like to cut down on the amount of internal bureaucracy at the CIA to the point where one person would manage the clearance process.

Herschler said the CIA is behind schedule on one volume; HDR has provided additional staff at the NSC, and HO will help the NSC with data-input. He said that two volumes have not reached the NSC, one is still at the CIA, and the other is at the Department of Defense, the 1958-1960 National Security and Disarmament volume.
Herschler then went on to discuss Guidelines for Declassification (Tab G).
Kimball referred to the phrase “informal appeal…” which appears on the last page of the Guidelines. He said that he thought HDR’s role in this process had already been defined.
Nelson asked if the work HDR does at State and at the NSC is a duplicate effort. Do they use different guidelines, she asked.
Chaddic said there were two HDR reviewers now three at the NSC who prepare documents and research on what is in the public domain but they do not make any declassification decisions.
Noring said that at the time of HO #1 memorandum HDR sends memos to the Desks to expedite clearance of volumes without appeal.
Herschler said that there are two volumes in preparation for referral, one on foreign economic policy and another on Congo and West Africa.
Kimball asked if the communication problem between HDR and HO had been resolved with appropriate liaison?
It is not a problem of liaison but rather HO keeping to its schedule, Noring said.

Slany said that 1995 could either be a good year or a down year, but in either case the outcome will affect the 1996 production schedule. He also said that delays at the NSC will be referred to Assistant Secretary Donilon for his assistance, and that the backlog problem is not a matter for the Committee.
Rosenberg, asked if the HO problem of meeting the FRUS production schedule was a staffing problem?
Slany replied that until HO had a full staff next year it cannot meet the schedule.
Nelson asked if it was a matter of setting more reasonable deadlines?
LaFantasie replied that the targets are reasonable but findings of new documents at the end of the process caused delays. He cited the example of the INR vault as a new source of documents.
Rosenberg commented that that was excusable and suggested the possibility of the need for a more flexible schedule.
Herschler said that when new documents were added HO must send them to HDR and to other agencies.
Noring said that HDR accepts late documents and it does not take its full 120 days to review FRUS manuscripts.
Slany said that he would like members of the Committee to review the Cyprus volume to determine if it is what we and the Committee’s constituents expect.
Kimball asked when should this be done?
Now, replied Slany.

Schwar said because of the requirements of the law, combined with the shortage of staff, HO sets compiling schedules based on the most favorable assumptions: everyone will be healthy, there will be no research snags, there will be no major declassification problems or additional assignments to take historians away from the volumes they are compiling.
The meeting recessed for a coffee break.
Chairman Kimball reconvened the meeting at 10:55 a.m. He asked the members if anyone felt a need for an executive session before lunch. All felt that it could be skipped.

He announced that Ann Van Camp would be in Washington next week to meet with David Langbart at Suitland to check on progress of preservation of State Department records. He also announced that she would be attending a meeting of an interagency group on electronic records.

Kimball raised a question about the Memorandum of Understanding with the Department of Defense. He read part of paragraph 7 and commented that the Secretary of Defense could deny the Advisory Committee access to records. He pointed out that that was illegal. Nelson said it depended on the level of security clearance of the Advisory Committee member.
Slany clarified that the Secretary of Defense could, under paragraph 5a, deny access, but he must justify the denial in writing.

Kimball then brought up paragraph 9, which referred to the President’s statement upon signing the bill into law. Picker suggested that the statement should be taken out. Kimball agreed that the phrase has no validity. Slany pointed out that the new E.O. will make this point moot.

Kimball called on Keefer to give his report on access to INR records. Keefer reported that HO historians were getting full access to records and had a standing invitation to explore code word material. Some documents have been added to Foreign Relations manuscripts and will go through the declassification process.
Kimball asked if the documents would be declassified by HDR. Keefer said they would be reviewed by HDR and agencies with equity.

Slany also brought up the question of the future permanent status of the records. David Langbart informed the Committee that there is a retirement schedule. He is working with INR and the Records Management staff to work out the details.
Kimball said that the Committee appreciates the efforts of all concerned -- NARA, Records Management, and INR -- to ensure appropriate access to and use of INR records.
Kimball then asked David Humphrey for the report on the status of the tapes at the Johnson Library.

Humphrey began his update by informing the Committee that there were 7,000 dictabelt recordings of Johnson’s telephone conversations, 2,000 of which had been transcribed or summarized. The Department of State’s initial request was to process transcripts of 400 conversations with Rusk, McGeorge Bundy, and McNamara, and this has now been moved to the front burner.
Herring asked if the 400 tapes covered the whole 1963-68 period. Humphrey said yes.

Nancy Smith said that the Library could not vouch for the accuracy of the transcripts, which had been done by the White House staff, not the Archives. Humphrey said that the recordings were useful as a starting point, but at least 4-5,000 tapes have not been transcribed. He said that the historians needed access to the dictabelts themselves.

Page Miller asked how many hours of conversations are we talking about. Humphrey explained that this was unknown because the project was still at a very early stage and some of the tapes have never been heard.

Humphrey reported that he was going to Austin at the end of May to discuss procedures, problems, a schedule for access, and possibly to look at transcripts if any were ready. Most have not yet been reviewed for privacy issues. The Library sees this as a staffing problem, and Humphrey commented that the Committee may want to recommend State funding of one position for 2 years to accelerate access.

Kimball asked if this was necessary. Humphrey said yes, from what the staff at the Library says, the material is valuable for Foreign Relations. He could only rely on people who are familiar with the material.

LaFantasie said that we anticipate this to be a rich resource and he hopes that the tapes will allow us to fill in gaps in the record or better record the outcome of a meeting. Maybe we won’t print the whole transcript, but use it for annotation.

Herring commented that the tapes were valuable because they give insight into Johnson’s character and attitude toward foreign policy. Nancy Smith pointed out that Johnson did not always commit to paper.

Rosenberg asked if annotation will be the primary way to use the transcripts; actual quotes will be more appropriate. LaFantasie said that he would not rule out publishing the transcripts. An oral source that constitutes a record will certainly be published.
Luke Smith said that we have set a precedent in using transcripts in the Cuban missile crisis. He put the information in editorial notes.

Glad asked about the general problem of declassification and how to excise material on the tapes. Humphrey responded that the majority may not be considered classified and that technology exists to cut out portions of the tapes.

Humphrey said that the HO researchers will decide which conversations to listen to by using the subject log and the transcripts. He said that, given the fact that Johnson wrote so little, these tapes are a very valuable resource.

Kimball asked what the Committee could do. Slany said the Committee must keep three things in mind: 1) this will take more resources; 2) this will have an impact on the schedule and will raise the question whether Foreign Relations volumes should be published without the tapes; and 3) the priority given to Foreign Relations compilers will hinder other users. We need some guidance on the hierarchy of importance. Is it worth slowing the schedule to ensure inclusion of this material?

Kimball said that unless the delay is “unconscionable,” the Committee would rather delay publication. Herring pointed out that this will have an impact on every Johnson volume. Leffler said it was important to know what was in the collection. Kimball asked how many person hours were needed at the LBJ Library to keep to the 30-year schedule and ensure access. How much delay and how big a job?

Rosenberg disagreed. She wanted to make a general endorsement of the importance but to make no specific recommendations. Kimball said the Committee needs to know what scale of resources will be necessary.

Smith said that, although there initially was a 50-year restriction on this material, Harry Middleton had decided to break the restriction to allow scholars access to the collection. But the tapes must still be reviewed under the donor’s deed of gift. Kimball asked if we could speed that process. Humphrey said it was hard to get a specific number of man hours but the Library needs immediate help to review the tapes.
Humphrey said that HO is compiling volumes now without this information, and we need to get access as soon as possible.

Van Camp said that the experience with the JFK tapes should afford the Library an idea of how much time and money would be required. Smith said she has budgetary figures for the JFK project that she will share.

Kimball pointed out that there are two parts to this issue: 1) this is a resource problem and the Committee recommends that State Department fund a position for 1 year to evaluate and help to get the material into Foreign Relations manuscripts; and 2) what impact will the priority given to HO historians have on other scholars.

Smith pointed out that the Johnson Library wants State’s help to get all the transcripts declassified and available to all scholars. Glad agreed that it was important to use the priority given to HO historians to open the door for other scholars.
Chalou asked about the preservation of the dictabelts. Smith and Humphrey assured him that the Library was already preserving the dictabelts.
Kimball said that Slany and Humphrey would work out a specific recommendation for the Committee to make to PA. This will be discussed tomorrow.

Rosenberg asked about the other volumes compiled without the tapes. She said she was uncomfortable with volumes being published without this material. Why wasn’t the Committee alerted about this earlier? Humphrey pointed out that the issue was a recent one. The collection was originally closed for 50 years, and only in 1993 was the restriction lifted.
Kimball said there are three categories of volumes: 1) those currently being compiled, 2) those ready for the declassification pipeline, and 3) those in the pipeline.

Picker asked about a separate volume of these transcripts. Kimball pointed out that this would mean publishing out of context. Picker explained that the legal profession handles these kinds of updates with a pocket in the front of the book to contain a subsequently published pamphlet.
Van Camp remarked that this is only the “tip of the iceberg.” This issue of oral records will only get worse.
Smith wanted to make three points:

list.item: 1) the conversations were not easy to understand
2) they were a running dialogue and switch from subject to subject
3) sometimes the tapes lead to different conclusions from the written record; if the transcript is published later, it might be misleading.

div.p: Leffler suggested holding back the 1965 Vietnam volumes because a lot of the discussion during this period concerned Vietnam. Kimball said that the Preface could refer to the tapes at the LBJ Library and note that they were not available at the time the volume was published.

Smith said that there are approximately 400 key transcripts. Leffler asked if they would be available in the next 12 months. Slany said it would be more likely if State funds a position. Glad said that the 30-year line should be pushed back to include this material.

Taylor asked how the transcripts would be declassified. Herschler said the declassification process was the same as for all Foreign Relations manuscripts, but the tapes must also be listened to. Luke Smith asked about the reliability of the transcripts. Humphrey said they are relatively accurate but that HO historians should compare a transcript to the corresponding dictabelt before publishing it.

Picker agreed with Glad that the completeness of the record was more important than meeting the publication deadline. We should try to establish a procedure or precedent to deal with this issue in the future.

Leffler reiterated that access will be available within 12 months and the Vietnam volumes should not be published without this material. Picker repeated that it was necessary to establish a consistent approach. Nelson said that the Committee needs to repair the volume (64 VN) that is out and hold the others for the tapes.

Kimball asked how many volumes are involved. Slany said only two would be held up. Kimball asked for how long. Humphrey said this would be a long project. Kimball asked how long it would take to identify key conversations and pull them out. Humphrey explained that the file HO had asked for was in alphabetical order, but the dictabelts were organized chronologically. It was his understanding that the Library will proceed chronologically in processing the dictabelts.
Kimball calculated a minimum of 18 months delay: 12 months to review the 400 key transcripts, and 6 months to declassify.
The Committee adjourned for lunch at 11:58 a.m.

Mr. Bennett Freeman, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs, joined the Advisory Committee for a working lunch. Mr. Freeman opened his remarks by asking the Committee for its response to the latest draft executive order on classification and declassification that had been prepared by the NSC.

Warren Kimball spoke for the Committee and said that it believed the exemptions were far too extensive and foreign government information was too stringent. In several instances the Committee recommended substitute language for various passages in the draft executive order, including those sections dealing with exemptions and the potential harm that release of U.S. and foreign government information might have on present U.S. foreign policy. Prof. Kimball also pointed out that the terms of the draft executive order essentially would create a 35 year implementation period rather than the intended 30 year period because an extra 5 years is allowed for phasing in. The
Committee, said Prof. Kimball, also saw a problem in the fact that the draft actually upheld page by page review, and that this could have a political impact by making it appear that the administration was not in favor of openness after all. The Committee also believed that the Appeals Committee should not be watered down in its authority and that its membership should include academics.

Mr. Freeman thanked the Committee for its thoughtful response, but he said that the situation presented a rather awkward one. The problem, he said, was that the Department had already delivered its own commentary upon the draft to the NSC, and Mr. Freeman could not thus encourage the Advisory Committee to send forward its own dissent. He recommended that the Committee devise a memorandum that elaborated its points, give the memorandum to the PA Bureau, and PA would send it forward to NSC. He said that in doing so, PA would have to point out that the opinions expressed by the Advisory Committee did not represent the Department or the Bureau.
The Committee agreed with this approach. Mr. Freeman said he would clear this approach with Mr. Donilon and would inform the Committee later whether the memorandum should be handled this way.
Kimball asked Nancy Smith of the Presidential Libraries of the National Archives to address the Nixon Presidential records issue.

Nancy Smith expressed her concern that the Advisory Committee be aware of the looming problem with the Nixon materials. So far, Nixon’s death had not changed the access situation regarding the Nixon Presidential materials. The National Archives (NARA) was currently being sued by Nixon, who contended that, before opening any additional tapes, NARA should complete its review of the tapes for personal and private material and return that material to Nixon. On the other hand, Public Citizen had sued because the tapes were not being opened quickly enough.

Smith emphasized that HO needed to begin negotiating with the Nixon lawyers and that it was better for State to negotiate directly with them rather than to go through the Office of Presidential Libraries, especially since the office was involved in a suit with Nixon.
Smith assumed that in his will Nixon had made provision for agents to carry on his litigation under the Presidential Materials and Recordings Act.

While many issues of privacy died with Nixon, Smith stated that there were 4,000 hours of voice-activated tapes. The tapes were being processed, but it was extremely hard to understand the voices on the tapes. As for the textual records, she hoped it would be possible to work out a partial processing arrangement, similar to that worked out with the Kennedy and Johnson libraries. There was a serious staffing problem at the Nixon project, since so much of the staff was tied up in the litigation issue, working on the tapes.

Jane Picker asked for clarification on the matter of agents having been appointed in Nixon’s will. Smith said that the issue of access was reserved for agents under the 1974 Act covering Nixon’s papers.

Smith noted that President Nixon was the last President to make tapes. David Humphrey added that the Archives has not yet begun to process Nixon’s National Security file. After some further discussion of the issue by the Committee on the probability that the Nixon family would want to release his foreign policy record, Kimball concluded that Slany should take up the issues raised by Smith and prepare a status report for the next Advisory Committee meeting, indicating what had been done and what was planned.
Ann Van Camp indicated that she was not able to come to Washington for a subcommittee meeting on Wednesday, thus she had no report to make.

In her report on the preservation and publication of the Department’s International Law Documentation, Jane Picker indicated that there was some possibility for compromise on the issue and she was waiting to see how the situation developed. Anna Nelson reported for the Subcommittee on the Opening of the Department’s 30-year old Records. Based on her and Arnold Taylor’s Wednesday visit to Suitland, where they examined documents concerning China, they recommended the following:

list.item: 1) that CIA send somebody out to Suitland or provide the State Department with the declassification authority for dealing with documents marked with the three letter acronym; the problem was widespread in the documents and was proving very time consuming to deal with.
2) that State be provided with DOD guidelines like those that NARA had from DOD. Currently State has to tab DOD documents for NARA, since it has no declassification authority itself.

div.p: Nelson also noted that State could not declassify ACDA documents, so they had to go to ACDA for review. Commenting on the random sampling procedure for examining files at Suitland, Nelson stated that the technique was adequate. Arnold Taylor stated that they needed to look at documents for more than one country before he felt totally confident.

Kimball stated that he had proposed to John Pereira of CIA that CIA provide guidelines for declassifying the three letter acronym. Kimball also reported that Pereira had stated that CIA was trying to arrange for a single person to make the necessary CIA declassification decisions for the project at Suitland.

Emily Rosenberg stated that State should get the three letter acronym issue made known to whomever in the Department could get it resolved, emphasizing the resources issues. Kimball asked if Assistant Secretary Kennedy was the appropriate person. He said he would get in touch with Kennedy, emphasizing the waste of resources in the current setup and the importance of notifying CIA of the problem. He asked Joe Chaddic and Slany to get back to him on the appropriate way to proceed.

Rosenberg asked Chaddic about the new declassification center. Chaddic responded that the center itself was not ready, but that the declassification work was already underway
with declassified files being placed in Ken Rossman’s area. Kimball stated that the committee would include in its annual report a statement that delays in establishing the declassification center were proving costly.
Melvyn Leffler reported on yesterday’s committee meeting with Gloria Boyd and John Pereira of CIA. Nina Noring was also present along with Edward Keefer, David Herschler, and Glenn LaFantasie.

There was positive news regarding China and Tibet. An agreement had been reached that one more review would be done by CIA, and Leffler thought there was a possibility of an acceptable compromise. So, given the prospect of an agreement, his recommendation was to wait one more time.
The news on the contested Japan and British Guiana documents was not nearly so good. The issues for the Committee’s decision were:

list.item: -- Should the documents in both cases be moved from the fiche to the print volumes?
-- Should the print volumes be published without the Japan and British Guiana sections or should the entire volumes be withheld?

div.p: Leffler proposed linking Japan and British Guiana to make clear that we cannot have a complete picture of our relations with those countries without acknowledging the certain activities. Kimball stated that this issue is going to come up again and again. He would like to get the issue as a policy matter out in the open. Alternatives included:

list.item: -- Prefaces explaining that the record was not complete;
-- A Department decision to publish the volumes against the advice of the committee;
-- Leaving the documents in the fiche and withholding the fiche publications, not the print volumes.

div.p: Kimball recommended that the British Guiana documents be included in the print volume because they provided such important insight into the Kennedy foreign policy. Betty Glad recommended withholding the print volumes and seeing what happens. Slany asked if linking the two countries was wise.

Kimball and Leffler stated their non-negotiable demand for the inclusion of intelligence information in the volume. Rosenberg asked if that kind of information was an issue that came up frequently, could we identify other instances and broaden the appeal? Had volumes been published without such information?

Leffler mentioned that during the previous day’s meeting Edward Keefer had outlined other instances of certain kinds of U.S. involvement in foreign elections during the Johnson presidency. Rosenberg asked if we were not making it appear that such involvements began with the 1960s, since they had not been included in previous volumes? LaFantasie said that the problem would be covered by a separate intelligence volume.

Ann Van Camp asked if the appeal process had been exhausted. If not, shouldn’t the appeal process be pursued to the end. Slany stated that the process had not been exhausted, an appeal had yet to be made to CIA, and a general discussion of appeal procedures ensued.

The Committee decided to recommend moving both the Japan documents and the British Guiana documents to the print volumes, publish the Northeast Asia volume without the Japan compilation, if the CIA’s involvement was not acknowledged, and withhold the entire American Republics volume if the CIA’s role in British Guiana was not acknowledged.
At this point the Committee adjourned for a coffee break. The discussion was continued after the break.
The committee reconvened at 3:15 p.m. and continued its discussion of declassification problems.

Kimball thought the Committee should give the Department and the CIA time to respond to HO’s appeals, and that if the problems were not resolved satisfactorily, then the Committee should recommend holding up publication. He stated that the subcommittee had set forth minimal requirements for the volumes. If (1) the Committee agreed and (2) the documents were withheld, then the Committee should advise the Secretary whether or not the volumes met the requirements and what should be done.

The question was raised whether CIA’s clearance decisions in these compilations could be appealed before State’s objections had been resolved. Kimball noted that different issues were involved. CIA had to address the issue of its equities in the documents, while State addressed the foreign policy implications involved. If the Department was unwilling to appeal, the Committee would have to do so.
Picker stated that the Committee needed to know where the barriers were. Slany noted that responsible officials needed to be informed and to have an opportunity to make decisions.

Kimball raised the question of whether the Committee should take a position on the issues involved at present. Glad noted that similar issues would arise again and again. She thought this was a propitious time to put pressure on CIA on this matter. Picker strongly supported Glad as to the opportunity presented by the political pressures the CIA was currently facing from Congress. Kimball concluded that even if State ultimately sought to deny publication of the documents at issue in the two compilations, it would go a long way toward a solution to confront and solve the CIA side of the problem.

Kimball reverted to the question of whether to move the contested material from the fiche to the print publications. He asked whether the committee agreed that the Japanese documents at issue belonged in the volume rather than in the fiche. There was general agreement. He asked whether they also agreed that the British Guiana compilation belonged in the volume rather than in the fiche. Again there was general agreement. Kimball noted that these changes would permit the microfiche compilations to go forward to publication. The committee endorsed the idea. Ted Keefer observed that he was being offered two fiche but no loaves.

Kimball asked whether the committee wanted to recommend publication of a Northeast Asia volume including the China and Korea compilations but omitting Japan, should the Japan clearance problems remain unresolved. Such a volume, he suggested, should include a preface indicating that the Japan compilation could not be published as a full and accurate
record of U.S-Japanese relations without the documents denied in the clearance process. The other option, he noted, would be to withhold the entire volume from publication. In that case, the documents declassified in the China and Korea compilations might be made available to researchers in a State Department reading room.

Taylor thought it was unnecessary to hold up publication of the China and Korea compilations in order to fight for the release of the contested material in the Japan compilation. Glad supported Taylor’s position. She thought withholding publication of an entire compilation, and emphasizing the omission in the preface, might have more public impact than withholding the entire volume. She felt, however, that the Latin America volume containing the compilation on British Guiana should not be published without the documents the Committee had agreed were essential to an accurate account. She also felt that the China volume discussed earlier should not be published without resolution of the clearance problems relating to Tibet along the lines of the minimum requirements outlined by the committee.

Kimball proposed that Glad’s analysis be adopted as the Committee position. The Committee agreed. Kimball added that it would lend impact to withholding publication of the Japan compilation if Japan was printed, along with China and Korea, on the spine of the volume. He also suggested the omission could be highlighted by including a separate statement in the front matter explaining the necessity to publish without the Japan compilation.

Van Camp pointed out that the law made provision for publication of descriptions of withheld documents. Kimball stated that the subcommittee had raised this with Gloria Boyd
and that the CIA is unwilling to declassify even the title of some of the documents at issue. LaFantasie stated that the question is whether the denied documents are crucial to the integrity of the record. Kimball suggested that HO ask CIA whether there are ways that summaries of the documents could be printed in lieu of the documents themselves.

Rosenberg asked whether the committee could expect to see replies from the Secretary of State and DCI concerning these problems at the next advisory committee meeting. Slany stated that HO would make every effort to obtain responses.

Picker asked, looking ahead, about problems that might arise in clearing language for prefaces to explain omissions growing out of declassification problems. Slany indicated that HO would address the question in the interim before the next meeting.

Moving on to the subject of the Department of State’s response to PRD-29, Kimball summarized the letter the Committee intended to draft in response to the position taken by the Department. The Committee had discussed the issue over lunch with Deputy Assistant Secretary Freeman and, at the end of the discussion, had decided that a response was necessary.

list.item:
(1) Kimball noted three specific issues concerning categories of documents to be exempted from declassification:
(A) The Committee considers that FGI should be submitted only to the same test as other foreign relations information. It thinks the Department’s language represents a retreat from the language of the draft executive order. The Department’s language provides for no drop-dead date on FGI. The Committee considers that the presumption should be that documents will be opened unless they meet an exclusion test.
(B) The Committee thinks the language should read: “reveal information that would cause exceptionally grave damage to U.S. foreign relations or endanger a living source.” It agrees with the removal of the words “between the United states and a foreign government” but objects to the phrase “foreign activities.” Picker urged insertion of the word “demonstrably” so that the language would read “demonstrably cause exceptionally grave danger. …”
(C) The Committee disagrees with the recommendation to change the authority of the appeals committee. It thinks that the appeals committee should be able to make decisions.

(2) The committee will point out that a 30-year rule with a 5-year phase-in period is in fact a 35-year rule. The committee is concerned that a 30-year rule would encourage page by page declassification review rather than a bulk approach. The letter will note that a 25-year rule is effectively a 30-year rule, which the State Department has previously supported. The committee will argue that to move to a 30-year rule, which would effectively be a 35-year rule, would be to move away from a policy of increased openness.
(3) The Committee disagrees with the recommendation to change the authority of the appeals committee. It thinks the appeals committee should be able to make decisions.

div.p: Kimball noted also that the committee intended to express a concern about undue layering in the appeals process.

Glad noted that the Committee would compliment the Department on its progress in reviewing the Department of state records under the legislation. Kimball stated that the
Committee appreciates the fact that many in the Department are working hard to open the Department’s records. Nelson noted that many of the concerns raised by the Committee would be raised by outsiders as well.

Machak was present during Kimball’s summary of the committee’s intended response to the State Department’s position on PRD-29. He expressed appreciation for the advance notice. He noted that the scheduled meeting of the electronic information group had been postponed to May 18. He stated that Van Camp’s perspective lent balance to the group’s deliberations, and he expressed the hope that Van Camp could reschedule her travel plans to enable her to attend the meeting.

Leffler asked Machak if outside researchers could be given access to the data base listing documents declassified by the State Department. Machak responded that there are some one million documents listed on the data base, which will soon be available to researchers in the State Department reading room. Leffler asked if the data base could be made accessible on the Internet system. Machak stated that the Department was looking into the possibility of making it available through the Internet system or putting it on a disk, which would be updated on a regular basis. Leffler requested that Machak summarize in a brief document what was available to researchers in the State Department and what was planned for the future with respect to making declassified documentation available to the public. Machak offered to provide a demonstration of his system at the next (August) meeting, rather than a document.

Nancy Smith noted that the draft executive order, like the present one, makes mandatory review open only to U.S. citizens. Presidential Libraries takes the position that mandatory review should be open to everyone, like the FOIA.
As the final business conducted by the Committee for the afternoon, Slany agreed to poll the committee concerning dates for future meetings. The committee adjourned for the day at 4:25 p.m.
The meeting was called to order at 9:08 A.M., Friday, May 6, 1994.

Kimball distributed copies of a recommendation written by Dr. Slany and David Humphrey concerning State funding of a person at the Johnson library to accelerate HO access to dictabelt recordings and transcripts. He also gave S. Taylor a diskette containing a memo drafted by Kimball and Herring and addressed to Assistant Secretary Donilon about the new executive order on declassification. S. Taylor was attempting to find a computer to convert the document to the Department’s word processing system and print out with copies for members of the Committee.
Slany advised the Committee that he anticipated that Assistant Secretary Donilon would visit the Committee meeting sometime between 9:00 and 12:00 noon.

LaFantasie presented his report indicating that research at the LBJ library was on schedule, and more trips to the Kennedy library were needed to complete the last Kennedy volume (Paul Claussen’s volume dealing with the United Nations, Scientific and Humanitarian Affairs).

LaFantasie said that HO is “casting its research net wider” to encompass still more documentation from other agencies, particularly the CIA, ACDA, AID, and Commerce. He mentioned the advances HO has made in access to INR files and the LBJ tapes, and that the plan is to incorporate all of these sources whenever possible in order to meet the requirements of the law.

He said that State Department documentation is no longer adequate to provide the complete historical record in a changing world of historical documentation. This changing world affects the way the Foreign Relations series is prepared and published. Foreign Relations is no longer the first place that people can get documents because of public access through FOIA and mandatory review. We have seen examples where researchers receive copies of documents through FOIA and then compare them to Foreign Relations for consistency.

Foreign Relations should remain the “master” of these documents, therefore, we need to make sure that we know more. We must have more background on the issues, not just the documents so that we can answer questions that historians ask, not just print documents. LaFantasie stressed the importance of addressing bibliographic issues, telling the reader what we have and have not consulted and why or why not.

Slany commented that the effort to find out what is already in the public domain makes it necessary for us to consult with the National Security Archive. Nelson added that the NSA zeros in on topics, not just documents.

Dr. Slany agreed and said that the antagonistic relationship between NSA and State must be bridged by us, so that we know what they know. The NSA is holding a conference in Georgia (United States) on SALT II. The Russians have come to State with their documents that they would like to release and HO has been assisting in getting the Department to agree to their release. Kimball commented that it was his understanding that USSR documents were not considered FGI by the State Department and wondered why State was reviewing them as we do not refer documents to them. Slany said that the Russians were being courteous, and that he understood that the documents were cleared by State yesterday (Thursday, May 5). Kimball pointed out that it was not a public relations coup by the State Department.

Nelson remarked that when researchers go to the National Archives, they still use Foreign Relations as a first step finding aid for research. Other records tend to be incomplete, and Foreign Relations is used because it is a complete story.

Kimball reported on the issue of CIA job and box numbers. He had raised this issue with John Pereira and Gloria Boyd (CIA) in the declassification subcommittee meeting on Wednesday. Kimball was concerned that CIA review responses “thanked HO for not publishing the job and box numbers.” Boyd said that job numbers are not always reliable and do not represent a good archival citation. She and Kimball discussed the possibility of including a note in the prefaces of volumes stating that these numbers are not always reliable.

LaFantasie said that he and Ken McDonald had discussed the issue and were looking to establish a far better method of citing CIA documents. McAuliffe concurred. Kimball said that
this issue should be settled quickly, and if not, HO should consider the idea of a statement in the preface.

Kimball inquired whether HO had made progress with the National Security Agency in arranging for an access agreement. He brought up the subject of the Tonkin Gulf intercepts, which should be part of the Johnson administration historical record. These are located at the National Security Agency. Herring pointed out that the Foreign Relations volume for Vietnam, 1964 had already been published.

LaFantasie continued with his report. He said that HO has initiated a program of outside review of volumes before publication. In the past, HO has reviewed the quality of volumes in increments, first the compiler, then the division chief, the General editor, and when necessary, the Committee. He has initiated a program of expert review in which active Foreign Service personnel, who are between assignments, review these manuscripts. With this program, these FSOs have so far reviewed or are reviewing 1961-1963, Soviet Union, and both 1961-1963 Cuba volumes. A Department notice went out reporting HO as a “short tour” assignment for Foreign Service Officers.

These reviews are not as effective as an academic peer review, LaFantasie said, but they can provide important insights, particularly on the completeness of the volume, based on their experience and knowledge obtained in the field. He said that it is difficult to use outside reviewers because they must have clearances. From his perspective, thus far the reviews have been mixed. Substantively they have been on the whole favorable. The reviewers prepare a report which is shared with the compilers. The report is discussed and changes to the volume are made if deemed necessary.

Slany pointed out that State, for budgetary reasons, is trying to limit its hiring of contractors. HO is required to use active duty Foreign Service Officers as a first step in order to demonstrate their effectiveness and justify the cost of outside academic peer reviewers. LaFantasie mentioned the problem of conflict of interest concerning cleared outside reviewers. Once they read classified material, they can never write on the subject.

Kimball asked why the documents were classified. Several people pointed out that these reviews take place as early in the process as possible, and are therefore done before the volumes have been completely cleared. Kimball asked if these people are reviewing the full manuscript. Herschler said that was correct and it included material recommended for excision or denial.

Leffler commented that he thought this program would help generate support for Foreign Relations in the Department but was not likely to lead to an objective review. He questioned the FSO’s ability to accurately identify the key historical issues. He said that HO should not react to outside critics (such as William Burr) because the compilers have a better overall knowledge and familiarity with the sources. He suggested having compilers review each other’s manuscripts. He said HO should ask itself, “are we looking at the best documents?”

Herring agreed with Leffler that reviews by FSOs are not likely to be objective, but that it was cost effective for the Department. He also raised a concern about the potential for losing time with these reviews. Slany said that these reviews do not slow down publication of the manuscript.

Nelson said that she also agreed with Leffler. She suggested that an FSO would see documents and want to take them out of the manuscript for reasons of sensitivity or embarrassment. Slany said it was more likely to work the other way around, the reviewers would question withholding information that younger FSOs recommend for excision or denial. LaFantasie said that there would be hairbrained suggestions by the reviewers, but that the role of a responsible General Editor is to weed these out.

Glad said that she thought it would be useful to get the “participant” reaction to the volumes as long as their criticisms are not taken too seriously. Kimball closed the discussion by stating that it was the consensus of the Committee that the in-house review is okay, but not as helpful as an academic, peer review.

Van Camp wanted to know more about the relationship between Foreign Relations and the National Security Archive. Slany explained that the National Security Archive is the largest user of the FOIA, and that when their cases are done by State, records are not returned to their original files, nor does State always have accurate records of the results of declassification actions. He said that as a result, the National Security Archive can be used in two ways, first as a means of finding documents that can no longer be found in State files, and secondly it can serve as a check on the declassification status of documents until the new interagency declassification database, proposed by the draft new Executive Order, becomes a reality.
Van Camp stated that we must be careful about using National Security Archive records because they do not always identify the correct provenance of documents.
Nelson commented that it should be used as a source only as a last resort. Kimball pointed out that it was just a safety check, and that he did not think it was a major issue.
Kimball then called on Harriett Schwar for her report on Iran document.

Schwar referred everyone to her written report in the briefing package. She reported that the History staff at the CIA (especially Scott Koch) has been very helpful in getting documents from DO (Directorate of Operations). However, she added that for awhile she was not allowed to look at the documents he discovered. She now has enough information to tell a story, as she has Kermit Roosevelt’s documents, which are very rich and explain the lack of documentation. This collection of documents does not contain telegrams. In the past, Jack Pfeiffer found some carbon copies of telegrams from poor quality microfilm. There were problems identifying the provenance of these documents. Pfeiffer retyped the telegrams. They were denied release, but the Department still has copies. She added that she provided copies of these telegrams to Koch so that he could attempt to find the originals.
McAuliffe said that the historians at CIA did not even know about these documents until Schwar told them.

Schwar commented that there may be more material. There are carbon copies of some operations plans. There must be a ribbon copy that went to the White House from Allen Dulles to Eisenhower that shows approval of these plans, but she has not found it. She found it hard to believe that CIA did not keep these records. She commented that Dulles’ files have not been very helpful. Records show that some lot files were
destroyed. She said that INR has unretired files, so maybe CIA does too, and this should be explored. She noted possible clearance problems for this documentation.

Nelson asked about the meager size of the Dulles files. Schwar responded that they were very thin. McAuliffe said that Dulles was not a note keeper, there are “dibbles and dabbles” but not what you would expect.
Glad asked if Schwar was using oral histories for dates. Schwar responded that she is doing this on the side so there was not sufficient time to consult oral histories.

Kimball asked if she was focusing on what the CIA has on Iran. Schwar responded that she was exploring what CIA has in order to get a feeling about the amount of documentation there is, and that any new compiler will have to do the digging.
Nelson asked if there seemed to be enough documentation to keep searching. Schwar said there was, but she did not think there was enough for an entire volume.
Glad suggested a volume on Eisenhower covert operations. Kimball agreed, saying that an intelligence volume would be helpful.

An exchange was made about the telegrams that Schwar provided to CIA, and that they were not originally sent to CIA because they were denied at State. McAuliffe commented that the paper trail at the CIA has long since vanished. The DO is there to provide support to field operations, not to support historical research. Therefore, the history staff
has engaged in much “sleuth” work in looking for the microfilm containing the telegrams. They were not giving up, and she thought that they would find the microfilm.
Glad inquired about whether Schwar had used British sources to augment her research. Schwar said that the UK does not release intelligence records.

Keefer said that HO recently met with Heather Jasmine, the head of the British equivalent of Foreign Relations, who said that they were planning on producing a volume on the Middle East covering the 1950s, which would include Iran.
Schwar said that an intelligence volume would be interesting. Kimball suggested that they broaden the discussion to a retrospective volume on intelligence.

Slany said that Dave Patterson is now working on cleaning up an earlier retrospective volume on intelligence from 1946-1950. Editing will be done in the Spring. The office will then proceed to the retrospective volume suggested by the Committee.
Nelson said that from what she had heard, it must be a retrospective on several actions. Rosenberg agreed, adding that the volume would probably cover the 11 covert actions mentioned by Woolsey.
Slany commented that those are the known, but the unknown ones should also be found and documented.

Glad said that she thought it would be important to include something on the Hungarian revolt of 1956, Rosenberg suggested that HO prepare a written outline of what should be included in this volume as a handout for the next meeting. Kimball said that HO should work on getting State and CIA to acknowledge these operations, so that it is not a wasted effort.
Kimball then asked about the CIA’s current plans for publication.

McAuliffe said that she is worked on an unclassified history of the CIA, which she jokingly called “CIA, The Book”. She said that it would not contain any surprises, but CIA would be officially acknowledging some things for the first time. She is also checking the record for accuracy.

McAuliffe said that the History staff hoped to declassify Nick Cullather’s classified history on Guatemala, and that there was nothing startling here, but it would correct some inaccuracies. They are also working on classified histories on McCone, Helms, and Colby, which they hope to have declassified.

Kimball asked if there would be a conference that would include release of a book of documents on Guatemala. She responded that they are trying, but nothing had yet been scheduled. She said that they are planning a conference for which invitations had gone out, but the subject of the conference is classified.

Nelson asked if the Soviet strategic estimates are already out. McAuliffe said that one volume has been released containing economic and political estimates for the period 1950-1959. A volume on Soviet strategic estimates will not be
released until around November. Glad asked what years it will cover. McAuliffe said it will cover the period up to about 10 years ago.

Leffler asked about a CIA volume on covert operations. McAuliffe responded that Pereira’s staff was bogged down with reviews for Foreign Relations, JFK, and the block declassification of the 11 covert operations.

Kimball stated that the Committee was concerned about access and resources. He asked for reassurance that the CIA projects are not unearthing new documents that were not available to HO. He stressed that Foreign Relations has to come first as far as the Advisory Committee is concerned.

McAuliffe responded that her staff was more involved with finding documents than last year, because the staff has been increased. This includes finding computer records because these new people have more computer expertise. If any of these documents had not been available to Foreign Relations, it is because they are just finding them now. She added that their publication plan is not well-defined and that she and McDonald were meeting monthly with Slany and LaFantasie.

Kimball concluded with a few odds and ends: that Van Camp would be able to go to the records management conference on May 18th after all; that he would pass out the memo to Donilon (which S. Taylor had printed out); and that he would pass out the minutes of the April 11th meeting on the Executive Order. He volunteered that he did not see anything wrong with it except for a typo, and that he would assume it is okay with everyone unless they say something to him. He noted that Freeman told him that the NSC will complete its review of the agency comments on the draft Executive Order
today (Friday) and a revised text will be sent to OMB by May 13th, so it was important that the Committee get its comments to the NSC by the end of the day.
The Committee recessed for a coffee break at 10:30.

Kimball called the meeting to order. He outlined the remaining items on the Committee’s agenda, including the wording of a draft memorandum to the National Security Council concerning the draft Executive Order on information security management, the wording of a letter preceding a visit to the LBJ Library, and approval of the minutes of the April 11 meeting. Assistant Secretary Donilon might appear in the course of the morning for a brief introduction, and Deputy Assistant Secretaries McCurry and Freeman would be ready to deal with specific concerns.

Kimball noted that the committee’s memo for the NSC on PRD-29 had not as yet been sent to the PA front office, but he had secured PA’s agreement that after the Committee finalized the language it would be hand carried to the NSC. Friday was the last day for such submissions, and’ the NSC would be forwarding its recommendations to OMB for finalization the following Friday. It was not clear whether OMB would request public comment, so the Committee should get its views on record at this point.

Discussion of the draft reply focused on limiting the definition of “sources” for the purpose of declassification. The Committee sought to keep this term as specific as possible without becoming involved in listing all possible types of intelligence sources. In phrasing criteria for exempting
documents from automatic release after 30 years, Leffler recommended the phrase “endangering a living source involving drugs and terrorism.” Rosenberg proposed adding “nuclear proliferation.” Nelson pointed out the need for a phrase broader than “intelligence sources.”

The phrase “endangering a living human confidential source” should be retained in section 3B of page 6, but Rosenberg suggested changing “revealing” a foreign confidential source” to “endangering” the same. Otherwise a memorandum that read “The Prime Minister told me confidentially” could be held back. The committee also agreed on an exception covering “grave damage to foreign relations.”
Rosenberg left the meeting at 11:23, after which the Committee agreed the memo was ready to be put into final form. A five minute recess followed for consultation with Slany and Herschler.

The committee agreed to support sending a staff member to the LBJ Library to study the Johnson tapes. Leffler asked whether HO had an alternative plan in case it could not find funding to accomplish its mandated objectives. Slany replied that while there was an alternative plan, more funding would be preferable to attempting to carry out more work with the same number of positions. LaFantasie suggested that the subject not be discussed in the presence of NARA personnel. Leffler stated he was satisfied with Slany’s reply.

At 11:29, the Executive Session began, and Kimball invited staff comments. Keefer observed that HO was falling behind schedule because it was losing people more rapidly than it could fill positions. Two out of four vacancies had been filled, and now two more people were about to retire under the
buyout option. Kimball asked Slany to elaborate on the hiring process. Slany pointed out that HO could not take applications, but was dependent on candidates furnished by OPM, who might have government, but not necessarily historical, experience. OPM’s regulations made it difficult to hire specialists from outside the Civil Service. Limited appointments seemed to be the only alternative, and State was reluctant to authorize them. Picker suggested rewriting the job descriptions to include the sort of professional background required, but LaFantasie pointed out that terms like “familiarity with research” could be circumvented. Kimball proposed that Picker could assist in the preparation of job descriptions. The Committee unanimously went on record to support the hiring of qualified persons on term appointments because of the backlog of FRUS work and the problem of filling existing vacancies expeditiously.

Schwar pointed out that the law provided on the one hand for speed of compiling and on the other hand for comprehensiveness and thoroughness of research. The two were increasingly in conflict, and the burden was increased by the need to stop compiling in order to deal with declassification issues. Glad indicated that the Committee was well aware of the situation, and Leffler asked where the balance should be. Schwar replied that the Office needed more staff.

Glad asked if there was any advantage in working in the new genre of smaller volumes. Keefer indicated that this did not in itself represent a breakthrough. A broader universe of sources and the compression required by smaller volumes actually made the process more difficult. Schwar indicated that with each time period the documentation was growing while the space available was shrinking, with the 1960’s, because of technical feasibility, telegrams became longer. Compilers were forced to limit annotation while indicating other sources.

Keefer said that HO’s only hope was to acquire a full compiling staff. Young Ph. D. candidates would be preferred. Kimball asked about the status of the intern program. Slany said that State managed it centrally. HO tried to get an intern or two per semester, although the regional bureaus tended to get the pick of them. HO expected to get four interns this summer. Smith observed that interns were of limited usefulness for FRUS: by the time they learned the procedures, it was time to leave.
At 11:52 am, the Committee turned to preparation of its Annual Report, and the note-takers were dismissed.
